title: Impossible to remove a gpg key if created with spack gpg create
body:
By mistake I ended up with having two identical keys created with the same command 

```
spack gpg create adam adam@statystyka.net
```

```
$ spack gpg list
/home/adam/tmp/spack/opt/spack/gpg/pubring.kbx
----------------------------------------------
pub   rsa4096 2020-02-02 [SC]
      3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E
uid           [ultimate] adam (GPG created for Spack) <adam@statystyka.net>

pub   rsa4096 2020-02-02 [SC]
      D3D41FFBD3609A85B6C5ADF33592BF5DF7239CBC
uid           [ultimate] adam (GPG created for Spack) <adam@statystyka.net>
```

How can I delete any of them? When I do 
```
$ spack gpg untrust 3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E
gpg: there is a secret key for public key "3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E"!
gpg: use option "--delete-secret-keys" to delete it first.
==> Error: Command exited with status 2:
'/usr/bin/gpg' '--yes' '--batch' '--delete-keys' '3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E'
```

I tried inserting the --delete-secret-keys in any possible place like
```
spack --delete-secret-keys gpg untrust 3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E
spack gpg --delete-secret-keys untrust 3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E -- --delete-secret-keys
spack gpg untrust --delete-secret-keys 3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E -- --delete-secret-keys
spack gpg untrust 3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E --delete-secret-keys
#and even
spack gpg untrust 3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E -- --delete-secret-keys
```

I also tried 
```
$/usr/bin/gpg --yes --batch --delete-secret-keys --delete-keys  3C7904840D45DE4E84367BBB4BA651264731CF7E
gpg: conflicting commands
```

I am no expert on gpg, and frankly I don't care that much about the signing in the first place. Please make a error-free wrapper around the gpg or write in the documentation, that in order to use the binary signing, you must be fluent on handling the complicated `gpg` command line syntax.

   *   *   *
  
I use spack `0.13.3-935-0c0aba57` on Ubuntu 18.04.4 64 bit
